journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Nonlinear multi-objective receding horizon design utilizing state-dependent formulation

contrib-group.aff: Institute for Aerospace Studies, University of Toronto, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Hugh HT Liu, Institute for Aerospace Studies, University of Toronto, 4925 Dufferin Street, Toronto M3H 5T6, Canada. Email: liu@utias.utoronto.ca

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: The art of multi-objective design is to extract the best compromise among conflicting requirements. The analytical multi-objective parameter synthesis adopts closed-form specifications that make the multi-objective design in linear systems computationally efficient. In this paper, the analytical multi-objective parameter synthesis method is extended to nonlinear systems via the state-dependent coefficients parametrization method in combination with the receding horizon control technique. The novel contributions presented in this paper are demonstrated on two fronts. First, the objective functions in infinite-time domain are replaced by equivalent finite-time functions with certain terminal terms, where the analytical formulations for the finite-time functions are made available and offer a computationally cost-effective approach. Second, the stability is addressed by adopting the receding horizon control technique. In addition, the proposed design approach shows benefits over the conventional nonlinear optimal control method. Two numerical examples further demonstrate the promising features of the proposed design framework.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The control system design to satisfy a series of requirements has been sought after in both classical and modern control theories. Research has led to a rich collection of well known results in the field. The method using linear matrices inequalities (LMIs) is a representative work when multi-objective control is treated as a convex optimization problem.1 Scherer2 and Pendleton et al.3 formulated performance specifications into the LMIs and combined LMI-formed specifications into one framework. Besides the idea of LMIs, Halder and Kailath4 and Liu and Mills5 presented the state feedback mixed
H
2
/
H
∞
design. The challenge of these approaches, however, arises in practice due to their structural complexity. Alternatively, the multi-objective parameter synthesis (MOPS)6 is regarded as one practical solution to the multi-objective control problem. It tunes controller parameters automatically to meet system requirements. However, parameter optimization in MOPS relies on online numerical calculation of system requirements, as system requirements cannot be calculated directly. In order to overcome the limitation of the intensive computation, the analytical multi-objective parameter synthesis (AMOPS) for a linear time invariant (LTI) system was proposed.7 In the AMOPS approach, performance specifications and their gradients can be expressed analytically so that it is efficient for optimization of controller parameters. It has been demonstrated to have excellent performance in linear control design.

In our previous work,8 the nonlinear extension of AMOPS via the parameterization of state-dependent coefficients (SDCs)9 was investigated. In this approach, the linearization via the SDCs parameterization is feasible around a certain equilibrium condition (operating point), and the entire nonlinear system is described by a set of linear-like state-dependent forms about a number of operation points across its dynamic function. Obviously, the feedback control gain has to be optimized at each operating point. Even though it made promising progress in terms of multi-objective design toward nonlinear systems, challenges remain, especially in computational cost when a collection of operating points need to be calculated. In addition, its stability is still an open question.

The research work presented in this paper takes a different strategy in implementing AMOPS through the SDCs extension. The novel contributions are demonstrated in the following aspects compared with other existing approaches including our previous effort.8 First of all, the receding horizon technique represents a computational efficiency improvement over the previous step-wise optimization8 by introducing analytically finite-horizon specifications. Second, the equivalence of (infinite) analytical objective functions to the finite specifications is proved by introducing a terminal function. Meanwhile, the stability is also addressed by the terminal function. In addition, the AMOPS’s nonlinear extension (nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis (NMOPS)) via the SDCs parametrization in combination with the receding horizon technique shows benefits over the conventional nonlinear optimal control method (e.g. the state-dependent Riccati equation (SDRE)).

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The next section presents the framework of the NMOPS. During the framework presentation, the equivalence between infinite- and finite-time objective functions is guaranteed by introducing certain terminal terms, and the stability is also addressed. Simulation results are then presented in the following two sections for two nonlinear control problems. Finally, concluding remarks are offered.

sec.title: Nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis
sec.p:
The original AMOPS7 for linear systems proposed a set of analytical performance specifications: the transient tracking index

*
( x )
is sought step-wise to minimize the cost function (equation (3)).

In our previous work,8 the step-wise controller optimization equation (3) has shown promising progress in terms of the multi-objective design toward the nonlinear system. However, challenges remain. To be more specific, under the framework of the AMOPS, system specifications are defined in the infinite horizon, and each optimization occurs over the infinite period. For example, the tracking specification that includes the transient tracking index
δ
J
t
and the steady-state tracking index
δ
J
tss
is represented by

In this situation, the optimal control profile (
u ( τ , x ( t ) ) , τ ∈ [ t , t + T , … , ∞ ]
), developed by the step-wise controller8 at a sampling time t, conflicts with the optimal control profile (
u ( τ , x ( t + T ) ) , τ ∈ [ t + T , t + 2 T , … , ∞ ]
) developed at the next sampling time
t + T
. The conflict may degrade the system performance or worse, cause instability. Therefore, the infinite-horizon based step-wise optimization proposed in our early work8 not only has the disadvantage of computational cost, but may also cause instability of the system (when the control profile’s conflicts become severe). In this paper, the concept of the receding horizon is adopted to avoid such a conflict when finite steps (horizon) are introduced. The proposed method of this paper includes three primary approaches. The first approach is the finite-horizon formulation of state-dependent specifications. The second approach presents the equivalence between infinite and finite specifications, as well as the stability analysis. The third approach gives analytical finite-horizon specifications based on the AMOPS derivation.

sec.title: Finite-horizon formulation
sec.p:

sec.title: Analytical finite-horizon specifications
sec.p: We are now ready to present analytical finite-horizon specifications. In Jadbabaie et al.’s work,13 the finite-horizon specifications were calculated numerically using the Recursive Integration Optimal Trajectory Solver (RIOTS).14 However, the numerical solution is usually computationally expensive. One of the motivations in our investigation is to seek analytical expressions to calculate system specifications.

The feedback control gain K is solved by minimizing the weighted sum of specifications equation (22). The analytical forms of the terminal term

caption.p: Analytical specification expressions in finite horizon.

sec.p: Based on these three contributions (presented in three subsections), the overall method in treating nonlinear multi-objective control is summarized in Algorithm 1. The main concept behind this algorithm is offered by the following remark.

list-item.p: Remark 1. Nonlinear systems and specifications are presented in linear-like state-dependent framework, where the finite-horizon approach replaces the infinite step-wise controller8 to improve stability and reliability. The equivalence of finite specifications to their infinite-domain ones, as well as the corresponding stability, are ensured by introducing a terminal term. In the meantime, the computational benefit of using analytical formulation in AMOPS still carries through.

sec.p: Table 1 lists the analytical specifications in the finite horizon and Algorithm 1 gives the overall design procedure.

sec.title: The stall recovery problem
sec.p: The objective of this example is to design a flight control system which can guarantee a reasonable response when the aircraft operates at a high angle-of-attack region. This example comes from Garrard and Jordan’s work.15 It was shown15 that by using the nonlinear control method, the non-recoverable stall angle is postponed. In this paper, the same flight model (F-8 Crusader)15 is adopted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method (NMOPS). Simulation results show that the recoverable stall angle is further relaxed using the NMOPS method compared with the conventional nonlinear optimal control method (e.g. SDRE).
It is assumed that the aircraft is trimmed at Mach =0.85 with the altitude of 9000 m. The nonlinear longitudinal equations of motion of the F-8 Crusader are15
where α is the angle of attack, θ is the pitch angle, and q is the pitch rate.

The elevator control surface
δ
e
is the control input in the above dynamics. The form of the SDCs10 is utilized to transform nonlinearity into a linear-like formulation. Since the system is not affine in control, following the SDCs parameterization,10,16 the integral control term should be introduced to the original nonlinear system and the augmented system is then given by

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p:
The trim conditions are
α = 2 . 5 ∘
,
δ
e
= − 0 . 5 ∘
. Garrard and Jordan15 gave the result that by use of the following linear feedback controller

the aircraft stalls at
α = 23 . 5 ∘
.
The NMOPS is implemented to increase the recoverable stall angle. For comparison purposes, the SDRE10 control method is also applied. Further information about SDRE is available at elsewhere.16

Figure 1 shows the angle-of-attack response based on the SDRE method (dashed line) and the NMOPS method (solid line). Figure 2 shows the control inputs of both methods. The initial angle of attack is 25∘. The response of the NMOPS controller is faster than the SDRE controller. Furthermore, in the SDRE design, the cost function
x
T
Qx +
u
T
Ru
is utilized to define system specifications. However, in the NMOPS method, more system specifications are considered. For instance, the control rate specification
J
u
·
is included in NMOPS’s multiple indexes, but not in the SDRE’s index. This implies that the SDRE controller fluctuates more than the NMOPS controller. The control profile in Figure 2 demonstrates this implication. In addition, both the SDRE and the NMOPS need to tune some weights. Proper tuned weights imply the best system performance. In the simulation, it is observed that the weights adjustment in NMOPS is easier than in SDRE.

caption.p: Angle-of-attack recovery performance based on NMOPS and SDRE.
NMOPS: nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis; SDRE: state-dependent Riccati equation.
Elevator response of NMOPS and SDRE.
NMOPS: nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis; SDRE: state-dependent Riccati equation.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the non-recoverable stall angles of the linear controller15 and nonlinear controllers (SDRE and NMOPS). It demonstrates that by using the NMOPS the recoverable stall angle is widened significantly. This could be attributed to the fact that simultaneous satisfaction among the system’s specifications is achieved under the multi-objective framework.

fn.p: NMOPS: nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis; SDRE: state-dependent Riccati equation.

sec.p: The nonlinear F8 model has been simplified based on the assumption15 that aerodynamic coefficients are constant. In order to demonstrate the effectiveness of the NMOPS further, a more practical and complex flight model (X31 airplane) is introduced as the second simulation example. In this flight model, more nonlinear elements are included. For instance, aerodynamic coefficients are obtained from a nonlinear look-up table. Besides, the six-degree-of-freedom (6 DOF) flight dynamics are fully nonlinear.

sec.title: High angle-of-attack tracking problem
sec.p: The control problem in this example is to design a reasonable nonlinear controller that can provide acceptable tracking response over a step command of 50∘ angle-of-attack. The mathematical model of the aircraft is provided by Antony.17

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p:
The aircraft is assumed to be flying at the altitude of 1000 m with an airspeed of
V = 100
m / s
. The equilibrium states are
α = 5 ∘ , β = γ = p = q = r = 0 ∘
. The NMOPS design procedure is adopted to design the controller. The SDCs parameterization is adopted to linearize the system. The coefficients of the SDCs parameterization are listed in Appendix 3.

For comparison purposes, the SDRE is implemented again. Figure 3 shows simulation results of both designs. The results demonstrate that the NMOPS offers better tracking response over a step command of 50∘ angle-of-attack than the SDRE does. Moreover, Figure 4 shows the control inputs of both designs. In this particular simulation example, it is the canard and normal TVC that control the pitch of the aircraft. Therefore, except for the canard and normal TVC, other control inputs remain around the equilibrium state zero. From the plots of the canard and normal TVC, the similar phenomenon which the SDRE controller experiences a more dramatic change than the NMOPS controller does occurs again. It is a quite promising but not surprising phenomenon. As has been discussed earlier, the NMOPS design tries to compromise more performance specifications than the SDRE in its framework. For instance, the performance specifications of the NMOPS include the control rate index
δ
J
u
·
, whereas the specification index of the SDRE only includes system state and control input (
x
T
Qx +
u
T
Ru
).

NMOPS: nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis; SDRE: state-dependent Riccati equation.

sec.p:
For completeness, the tracking performances of all other states using the NMOPS and the SDRE are shown in Figure 5. Figure 6 shows the stability performance index
δ

of the NMOPS and the SDRE.

caption.p: Tracking performance of other states based on NMOPS and SDRE.
NMOPS: nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis; SDRE: state-dependent Riccati equation.
Stability performance based on NMOPS and SDRE.
NMOPS: nonlinear multi-objective parameter synthesis; SDRE: state-dependent Riccati equation.

sec.p:
As a result of the fact that the NMOPS design tries to meet various performance objectives simultaneously, it can be concluded from these two examples that the NMOPS, adopting a group of system specifications, performs better than the SDRE that adopts the weighted system state and control input (
x
T
Qx +
u
T
Ru
).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, the SCDs parameterization in combination with the receding horizon control technique was utilized to solve the nonlinear multi-objective control problem. Our contributions can be summarized as follows: first, the finite-horizon approach was proposed to replace the infinite step-wise controller to improve stability and reliability; second, the terminal term was introduced not only to bridge between infinite- and finite-horizon specifications but also to address the system stability issue. Finally, by adopting linear-like state-dependent framework, the computational benefit of using analytical formulation in AMOPS still carried through. Simulation results of two nonlinear control problems demonstrate that the proposed method is promising. On-going research includes comparison of other nonlinear design approaches, more application cases, and rigorous proof of the design framework.
